utterances.speaker: CHUCK ROSENBERG, FORMER ACTING HEAD, DRUG ENFORCEMENT ADMINISTRATION
utterances.sentences: When Mueller indicted those Russian military intelligence officers, there was a very big hint in that indictment that there was an American deeply involved. I talked about an American playing a role in that Russian interference scheme.

utterances.speaker: NICOLLE WALLACE, DEADLINE

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Emailing with Russians, that's all it takes now to destroy a life. It's been enough to destroy Carter Page's life. Remember Carter Page? He graduated at the top of his class at the Naval Academy. He served this country for five years as an Intelligence Officer, and then he made a fateful mistake. The ghouls on cable news kept up the drumbeat, "Carter Page. Russia. Carter Page. Russia." Before long, Carter Page's life was over. His reputation was gone. Who would hire him now? Nobody, ever. But the ghouls don't care. They're on to the next victim, and so is Robert Mueller. Maybe it'll be Jerome Corsi this time, facing a criminal perjury count. Maybe someday, it will be you. They'll make up some official sounding charge. But don't fool yourself. What they're really punishing is disobedience. Jonathan Turley is a Professor at George Washington University Law School and he joins us tonight. I am confused by the focus on Roger Stone and Jerome Corsi and Carter Page, and people who, you know, whatever you think of them, approve or disapprove, aren't - clearly not central players in a Russian espionage plot.

utterances.speaker: JONATHAN TURLEY, LAW PROFESSOR, GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY LAW SCHOOL
utterances.sentences: Well that's the striking thing is that most of the counts brought against non-Russians are for false statements or collateral crimes. And if - if the culmination of this investigation will be someone like Stone or Corsi, it looks like you're running around shooting the wounded. I mean it - there - there's not - there still isn't a clear "There" there in terms of a central figure doing some substantive criminal act. And this is going to be defining (ph) moment for Mueller in that sense. You know, he's supposedly working on his report. He's closing in on a new group of - of indictments. And what a lot of us are wondering is if these indictments are going to bring some powerful narrative end to this. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: You know, because this sort of feels like an Agatha Christie, where no one's telling you a thing till the last scene because right now it doesn't look like he has really found central culprits, people who are actually colluding with Russia.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Because if you applied the standards that he applied to General Flynn, whom I'm not defending, I'm agnostic on General Flynn. But just being honest, having lived here all your life, if you applied those standards to any public figure in Washington, who couldn't you indict for criminal perjury?

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, false statements is the darling of prosecutors in Washington. It is very easy to trip someone up to go under with U.S.C. 18, U.S.C. 1000 - 1001. And any statement you make of that is false on any subject to a federal investigator can be charged, and they certainly did that here. If you take a look at some of these - these statements, Flynn's case is really quite weak, if you look just at - at that false statement. I mean they're originally the - the FBI agents were not viewing that as a criminal matter. Every indication we have is that when Mueller came in, they converted it into something they wanted to indict for. There's no indication that when they saw that that statement is being false or misleading, they viewed it as a criminal act. And so, the real question for Mueller is - is - is whether at the end of this investigation, I do think we can see it from here, are we going to have a figure step forward where you go OK, I get it. You know, you were on this guy's-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. For sure (ph)--

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: --this guy's pair (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --tell me what it is.

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You know, I want to arrest the perpetrators.

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: Right. But, you know, someone like Stone - Stone himself says he's a performer.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: And to indict him is like shooting a mime in Central Park. He's an annoying character, perhaps, but you're still wondering why did you wait all this time to indict Roger Stone? And, you know, all the earlier filings--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: --said that they have no evidence that anyone knowingly engaged the Russians, and that would have included Stone. So, we'd have to see a very new shift in the narrative from the past filings.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I think it's disgusting. Professor, thank you--

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --very much. Mollie, I guess I'm really struck by the individual. I think we should all care most about the individual. What happens to the American citizen, the actual person? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } And I'm seeing a trail of people who really have been destroyed, and I'm seeing people on cable television laughing about this. The moron we just played a second ago, this is great, whatever but these are actual people who are being destroyed. And I'm wondering what the rest of us are gaining from this?

utterances.speaker: MOLLIE ZIEGLER HEMINGWAY, SENIOR EDITOR, THE FEDERALIST, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well and it isn't just about the individual, I think, also rule of law, in general.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.sentences: There's broad leeway in how you prosecute - prosecute something. The Department of Justice chose differently when it was investigating Hillary Clinton. They had a lot of people up to and including Hillary Clinton on false statement charges. If you read the Inspector General Report about - that looked at that investigation, they knew they had Hillary Clinton on making false statements. She was never charged with a crime even though she could have been. And this isn't even mentioning that she could have been charged with all sorts of crimes with her how she handled her classified information. So, you want to not just have fairness in how you handle an individual investigation but across different investigations. When you see that one group of people gets away with anything, no matter what it is, and another group of people gets brought up on processed charges, when we were promised, quite dramatically, treasonous collusion with Russia to steal the 2016 election. And that's not a good sign (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Doesn't it - I mean one of the costs here is the cynicism this engenders in all of us. I mean we don't believe in the system anymore to be frank (ph). if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.sentences: Well I mean there's a reason we've talked about how in other countries they find the man and then they find the crime. They decide someone's guilty and then they figure out how it's done. That's not how we're supposed to do it in this country. We're supposed to start with a crime and then work back from there.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY

They've made it so that it's hard for people to stand up and--

utterances.sentences: I - I know a lot of them personally.

utterances.sentences: Thanks. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --very much. Well the Central American migrant Caravan is a myth. You've heard that many times. One reporter went to find out for himself. He investigated it. And we'll show you what he uncovered after the break. Also, more on the Florida recount and the associates that Hillary Clinton sent down to influence it. Hillary Clinton is back. We've got details. Filmmaker Ami Horowitz traveled to Mexico for a firsthand look at the migrant caravan from Central America.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well the migrant Caravan is fake. You've been watching CNN so you know that. Look at this graphic quote, "INVASION" then the word MYTH on the screen. It's a myth, a pernicious one too. Is it actually a myth? Well filmmaker Ami Horowitz decided to find out himself. He went to Mexico looking for this fake Caravan. He found a real Caravan and he filmed it. Here's part of what he found. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: AMI HOROWITZ, AMERICAN DOCUMENTARY FILMMAKER
utterances.sentences: Despite the framing of the Caravan as being full of women and children, the reality on the ground is quite different, approximately 90 to 95 percent of the migrants being male. The major narrative being pushed by the press has been that the migrants are leaving Honduras because they're escaping extreme violence and that their lives are under constant threat, setting up the strategy that they would be able to enter the U.S. by asking for asylum. So, I started by asking them a simple question. Why are you coming to America?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (FOREIGN LANGUAGE).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE (THROUGH TRANSLATOR)
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm looking for a better life. Economic.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE (THROUGH TRANSLATOR)
utterances.sentences: I wish to get there and work there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE (THROUGH TRANSLATOR)
utterances.sentences: Being in Honduras there are no jobs.

utterances.speaker: HOROWITZ
utterances.sentences: There was a massive logistical effort underway akin to moving an army and is clearly costing someone millions of dollars for the transportation, food, water, medicine and services that are being provided for the members of the Caravan. The Mexican government also seems to be sending police to escort the dozens of buses and trucks that are ferrying the migrants and supplies along the route to the next destination.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE (THROUGH TRANSLATOR)
utterances.sentences: The buses have arrived, people! Let's go! Four more buses are coming!

utterances.speaker: HOROWITZ
utterances.sentences: Ever-present among the thousands of migrants are workers of Pueblo Sin Fronteras clad in black T-shirts and colored vests. Pueblo Sin Fronteras means people without borders. They're the ones that seem to be most involved in organizing and mobilizing this Caravan. The organization, as the name implies, is looking to create a world without borders, which seems to be one of the reasons why they organized this Caravan in the first place, to flout American sovereignty. While it does seem as the majority of these migrants are friendly and simply trying to make a better life for themselves and their families, there's an undeniable element of the migrants who are violent and dangerous. And many of the migrants know this and some have experienced it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE (THROUGH TRANSLATOR)
utterances.sentences: Yes, there may be some bad people here.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE (THROUGH TRANSLATOR)
utterances.sentences: Actually, during the journey we've been victims of violence, verbally and physically.

utterances.speaker: HOROWITZ
utterances.sentences: It seems to me that there are Leftist organizations that are using these migrants as a tool to push a certain political agenda, which includes the weakening of American sovereignty and our border security. And unfortunately, these migrants are going to be caught in the crossfire.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Ami Horowitz joins us tonight. That - well that was really interesting. The thing that jumped out at me was how, as you said, well- organized it was. Do we have any sense who's paying for this? I know we're not allowed to speculate. But do we know that answer?

utterances.speaker: HOROWITZ
utterances.sentences: We - we don't. We know - what we do know is this whole thing cost millions and millions of dollars. And - and the mainstream media and - and there's so many layers to this onion to peel back, it's hard to know where to begin. But one of the lies, the fake news, if you will, that the mainstream media is trying to propagate is the fact that this is all this weird, this organic thing and all the water and the food and the medicine all dropped from - manna from heaven. It's baloney. It's all highly organized. It's paid for by a number of organizations. We don't know exactly where the money is coming from. We do know that that Pueblo Sin Fronteras, which is the - the main group, which organized this Caravan has a couple of front organizations in the United States, and the money is flowing from them to Pueblo Sin Fronteras. We know there are some Leftist groups. I know it's - it's - it's forbidden to say that Soros is part of it. But Soros has, in fact, funded at least some of those groups in the past. So, we don't know where the money is exactly coming from. But we know it's not coming from Honduras.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So why would - I mean it's such an interesting and obvious question. Who's paying for this? Why haven't other news organizations gotten to the bottom of this? You're one man. You're doing this independently. Why isn't NBC News or ABC or PBS, why aren't they on this?

utterances.speaker: HOROWITZ
utterances.sentences: Oh, come on. You know the answer to that. They don't want to get to the bottom of it. They have no - they have no interest politically--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HOROWITZ
utterances.sentences: --they'd gain (ph) from the bottom of it. It's the same reason why they - whenever you see - when you see a photo in The New York Times, The Washington Post or a video in - in CNN or the BBC or MSNBC, what do you see? You see the whole - the entire framing are women and children, when the reality is so far from the truth. 90 to 95 percent of all the people who are in this Caravan are men, although I do apologize for assuming their gender.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They're liars. That's - that's the answer. And that's why they aren't reporting and then you are (ph) because they are liars. Ami, thank you for that. That was valuable and really interesting. I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: HOROWITZ
utterances.sentences: My pleasure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well there's a huge debate right now over the question of nationalism. Some people say the word itself ought to be banned, struck from our vocabulary. But, why? What is nationalism? And why is it bad to put America first, if you're leading America? We'll take that question up after the break.

utterances.speaker: DONALD J. TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: You know, they have a word. It sort of became old-fashioned. It's called a nationalist. And I say "Really? We're not supposed to use that word? You know what I am? I'm a nationalist, OK? I'm a nationalist."

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Not too long ago, it wouldn't have seemed strange for an American President, to call himself a nationalist. Lincoln was a nationalist, so was Teddy Roosevelt, Franklin Roosevelt, all very successful presidents. But this President's critics say it's not just wrong to call yourself a nationalist, it's immoral. And the French President agrees. Emmanuel Macron, who, by the way, has copied the style and, to some extent, the substance of Charles de Gaulle, a nationalist French President. But whatever, he attacked Trump by bashing nationalism. Why has this become a theme? Putting your own country first is not allowed. We'd like to get to the bottom of it. Jim Kessler is Senior Vice President for Policy at Third Way, and he joins us tonight. Jim, thanks a lot for coming on.

utterances.speaker: JIM KESSLER, SENIOR VP FOR POLICY, THIRD WAY
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, sincere question, so nationalism, there have been people who've claimed the title of nationalist who've had (ph) all kinds of creepy agendas that normal people, including me, would disavow, of course.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But, strictly speaking, the definition seems a common-sense one. A leader of a nation state puts the interests of that state above the interest of other states.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Well, of course--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --why is that bad?

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --I mean of course, a leader's going to put the interests of their own country ahead of others. That's not nationalism. Nationalism is a loaded term. I mean the definition of patriot - patriotism is, "I love my country," and nationalism is, "I hate your country." That's what it - it certainly has become.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Really? When--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: And--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --when did it become that? I don't - I'm - like who - who came up with the idea that that that's the definition? I missed that.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Well the definition of nationalism, especially when you're in the European context, where President Trump made that statement, is the nationalism that engulfed Europe in the 1920s and 1930s. The Nationalist Socialist Workers' Party that's the end for Nazi is - is that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. OK. But - but hold, wait, but--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --and that's loaded. And he knows that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --hold on. Hold on.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Hold on. Gandhi was a nationalist, OK, so the leaders of almost every nation stayed in history up until about 20 minutes ago would describe themselves and did as nationalists. So, I - I get what you're saying. But it seems a little too glib and - and pretty unfair. Let's address the substance of it. So, we have all kinds of multi-lateral agreements with other countries. A nationalist would look at those agreements and say, "I want to make sure that my country doesn't get hurt in this agreement."

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The Court (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Why not?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --for example.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But that's not the way that our leaders who benefit from a borderless world, the finance community, for example, which has gotten so rich, doesn't benefit from that. And so, they attack the idea of the nation-state. Why would it be wrong to push back and say, "No, no, the United States shouldn't get shafted."

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Of course, look, if the def--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, not of course.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --if the def--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Not of course.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --if the def - definition of nationalism was Gandhi's nationalism, we wouldn't be having this discussion.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: There's (ph) American nationalism--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: But - but--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --Roosevelt's nationalism.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --Ronald Reagan never used the term nationalist. He used the term patriotism. And especially, Donald Trump is using this as a weapon. He's using this as separating the - the - this nation.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Separating who? I don't know (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --who's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --from other nations? Why - why would that be bad?

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --so, certainly in the European context, everyone knows that nationalism is what led to the rise of Nazi Germany. And when he says that the French are nationalism--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. But you're throwing the (ph) Nazi thing out here (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --of course they're not (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --but hold on, but let's - let's--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --well that's where he did it, OK?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --no, no, no, no, he did it also in this country and I'm doing it here because I think it's important to have an adult conversation--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --not one where you win by innuendo, the end of Nazi is national (ph), OK, OK fine. But sincerely, I don't understand why the average person living in any nation-state wouldn't want his leaders to put his interests above those of other countries? And we don't, consistently we don't.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I can give you 10 examples. And you know what I'm talking about.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. And look, of course, you want your leaders to put the - the interests of your nation ahead of others. That's what national - nationalism is not that. Nationalism is basically saying our country is always right. There are other countries, they are always wrong. And it is to separate us from other countries. And that's - and he is using that term as a weapon--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But - but - but - but so--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --and this is - his strategy is always to divide and conquer.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --OK. But - but - but hold on--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: And that's what he's trying to do with nationalism.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --OK but, I guess that you're coming at this believing that all countries must be united somehow.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: No. There are (ph) countries, of course, are going to have conflicts.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But what unites Americans? So, if not a shared loyalty to the country--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. It's melting pot--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --they live in--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --national identity--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --those are important things.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well but what would be more important than that like so what does hold this country that doesn't have a common race or religion or history and that's all fine as far as--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I'm concerned. But what does hold us together if not nationalism?

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: A common center of (ph) ideals and beliefs and belief in democracy, and a belief in pluralism, and a belief in the American Dream and being inclusive. And I think those are the American values and those are not nationalist values.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well sure (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Nationalist values are basically separating into sort of the in- group in this country and the out-group in this country. And if it--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, wait, wait, but - but maybe you're misunderstanding the term. So nationalism, by definition, includes everyone within the nation. It does not exclude fellow American citizens. It unites them. And at a time when the Left is hell-bent, as you know, on dividing us by race, which is the - the basis of--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: I disagree with that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --well no, but identity politics is--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --the - the whole concept is we are - we owe our first allegiance to our tribe--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: So, I'm a - I'm a melting pot--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and that's obviously less interesting work (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --Democrat--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Amen (ph) I mean--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --good for you. And we - we agree on that, certainly. But at a time when we are divided by tribe, why wouldn't nationalism be the answer to that? We're all in it because we're Americans.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: So here's my question then. Ronald Reagan wouldn't say it. George H.W. Bush wouldn't say it. Bill Clinton wouldn't say it. George W. Bush wouldn't say it. And Barack Obama wouldn't say it. But President Trump said that and he said it in European context--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's the argument that Bill Clinton and George W. Bush--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --now and--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --wouldn't say it?

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: And Ronald Reagan wouldn't say it but--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're not winning me over.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --but - well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's not an argument.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Because you don't want--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's an observation.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --OK. It's an observation - because that word is now a loaded term based on what happened in the 1920s and 30s, and you know it. Nationalism--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --is not the benign, you know, Teddy Roosevelt--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, and I mean, you know what--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --Abraham Lincoln nationalism.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --let's reclaim that word because--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's been 80 years. And it's I - we defeated the Nazis. Americans died to defeat them.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Yes, we defeated--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank God.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --we defeated National Socialist German Workers' Party--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We didn't defeat, no, we--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --of the Nazis.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --we defeated the Nazis.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And that has nothing to do with what we're trying to tell (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: So, do you think when Donald Trump was talking about nationalism in France and to Macron, he didn't know what he was doing and referring to the Nationalist uprising--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Didn't surprise enough (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: --in the 20s and 30s (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --Macron is himself a nationalist, whatever. We're out of time. I wish we could - I hope you'll come back because I think (ph) it's interesting--

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: I would love to.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --to have an (ph) important conversation, thank you.

utterances.speaker: KESSLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well just when you thought the Florida situation couldn't get any weirder, a former presidential candidate from last time around got involved. What is her plan? We'll tell you after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well the election recount going on in Florida tonight has been sorted enough. But now Hillary Clinton has gotten involved. And if you don't like it, you're a sexist. Clinton is deploying organizers and lawyers to Florida. It could be setting up a third presidential run for her, more evidence that God may be punishing America. Independent Women's Voice Senior Fellow Lisa Boothe joins us tonight to decode these latest events. What is she doing down there? And what does it mean?

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, FOX NEWS CO-HOST, OUTNUMBERED, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S VOICE SENIOR FELLOW
utterances.sentences: Well so she sent out a fundraising pitch on behalf of the DSCC as well as Bill Nelson for specifically for attorneys and organizers to get down there and fight for this election. And I found it interesting for two reasons. One, obviously, this comes on the heel of the Wall Street Journal column written by Mark Penn, and I think it was Andrew Stein as well, basically saying that Hillary Clinton is going to run again in 2020.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: And then the second reason I found it was interesting is she took a swipe at Rick Scott and President Trump. And right now, the narrative from the Left is that they're trying to undermine the Florida election. What do you think Hillary Clinton has been doing since 2016? She has explicitly blamed Russia for her election loss saying that it wasn't Trump that got elected. It was at the hands of Vladimir Putin. And also, John Podesta who was her Campaign Chairman, he was encouraging this effort for faithless electors that was organized by Nancy Pelosi's daughter. So, what do you think those two things do to undermine Americans' faith in the system?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It doesn't count though because that's Democratic officeholders. I mean come on, Lisa, you know the rules.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I know. I should - I should know better by this point, right?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You should.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thanks--

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: The rules only apply to Republicans it seems so--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's what I (ph) noticed.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: --yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Lisa Boothe, thank you for that.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.  Jeff Bezos wins Amazon's second headquarters sweepstakes In return for billions of dollars in taxpayer subsidies, Amazon announces its two new headquarters will be in New York City and northern Virginia; analysis from Brian Brenberg, associate professor of business and economics at The King's College.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, news from the tech front tonight. Amazon has announced, after months of hype, that it's building two new headquarter facilities, one outside New York City, and the other outside Washington and Arlington, Virginia. In return for bestowing his grace on America's two richest cities, Jeff Bezos, who is the world's richest man will receive more than $2 billion in subsidies from you, the taxpayer. Well new Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez had this to say today. "Amazon is a billion-dollar company. The idea that it will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks at a time when our subway is crumbling and our communities need more investment, not less, is extremely concerning to residents here." Hate to admit it. But Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has a very good point. Brian Brenberg is Associate Professor of Business Economics, The King's College. And he joins us tonight. Professor, thank you very much for coming on. That's the only time I've ever agreed with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN BRENBERG, PROFESSOR, EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT AND CHAIR OF THE PROGRAM IN BUSINESS AND FINANCE, THE KING'S COLLEGE
utterances.sentences: Ha-ha.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But it's hard to argue with the internal logic of her point. The richest man in the world just got $2 billion in taxpayer subsidies--

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --how does that work?

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: --and he's been shopping around the country for 14 months going to cities to see who will give him the best deal. And he's shaking down New York City for about $1.5 billion and he's done some - something similar down in Northern Virginia. And again, the whole point is he's trying to cozy up the politicians so that they will give him and his company, a $200 billion company, the biggest tax breaks around, and put them in a position where they can fend off competitors for years to come because they're cozy with the rule makers.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wait. So, you're saying that they're paying him to lobby them and then you see Adam Schiff, the incoming Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee saying he's going to investigate the President for daring to criticize Jeff Bezos.

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, no, no--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's making my head spin.

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: --Jeff Bezos is moving into town because he wants to control these narrative. He wants to control what's happening in the Halls of Power. He's already hired $13 million worth of lobbying and a 100 lobbyists to deal with this. Now he's going to put 20,000 more people right next to D.C. and Northern Virginia to make sure every time there's an issue that affects Amazon, he has boots on the ground in the Halls of Congress, in the offices of politicians to get his - his preferences passed, even if it means consumers and other small businesses lose out. This is all about getting his hands on the levers of power.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Can I ask you a question as an American? I should just say I'm a property owner in the District of Columbia. This makes my property values go up. I guess it's good for me. But having lived here for a long time, I can tell you, the last thing we need is more money in Washington. It's rich enough. Why wouldn't Amazon, subsidized by taxpayers, spread the wealth maybe to Detroit or Cleveland or Toledo or someplace that actually needs it?

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't understand.

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: --because, Tucker, Detroit isn't anywhere near Congress. Austin, Texas isn't anywhere near Congress. Dallas, whatever the city, this is purely a play for Amazon to buy political influence. They look around the world and they see potential competitors. They like being on top and they want to keep it that way. And the way to do that is to write the rules, to write the regulation. They are buying prime real estate where all those rules are written. Amazon has gone from a company that disrupts industries to a company that stays on top by buying--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: --political influence.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's exactly right. And it's got a whole political party protecting it.

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: They had pocket (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's unbelievable. It's the Democratic Party--

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: And even more so.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --party of big business. Professor, thank you very much for that analysis.

utterances.speaker: BRENBERG
utterances.sentences: You bet.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it. Well something pretty remarkable and very strange just happened in the skies over Europe. Authorities are looking for an explanation tonight. We don't know what it is but we have some facts about what happened. The truth could be out there. We'll bring those to you when we come back.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: THE TRUTH IS OUT THERE?

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: THE TRUTH IS OUT THERE?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: A very strange event recently in the skies over Ireland. Two different commercial airline pilots reported seeing unknown objects moving very quickly, remarkably quickly, through the sky. Irish Aviation Authorities have launched an investigation into it. Because we are interested in what is true, we asked Brett Larson of FOX News Headlines 24/7 to dig into this a little bit and he joins us tonight. BRETT LARSON, ANCHOR, FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7: I just flew in, Tucker. It is another one from the X-Files. Several airline pilots flying across the Atlantic saw something out there, a bright light in the sky, moving at what the pilot thought was at least Mach 2 or two times the speed of sound. Concerned for what it was, both pilots on a British Airways flight from Montreal to London, Heathrow contacted Air Traffic Control first to inquire if there was a military exercise, and then told Air Traffic Control--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There appears to be multiple objects following the same sort of trajectory, the path (ph). They're very bright from where we were.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It flew kind of (ph) on our left-hand side and then rapidly veered to the north. We just saw a bright light and then it just disappeared at a very high speed. We were just wondering - we didn't think it was a likely collision course. We were just wondering what that could've been.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: So multiple pilots reported these lights. But as an astronomer chimed in on the sighting, it suggests it could likely be a piece of dust entering the Earth's atmosphere at a very high speed. November, busy time for shooting stars. Pilots, including our men and women in the military, have reported similar sightings in the past though never dismissed as simple space dust.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What's so striking about this, Brett, is that it's not ordinary people drinking beer and fishing--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --who saw this. The people (ph)--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: And steering off into the sky, yes. These are--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly right. These are commercial airline pilots who--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --by definition are experts at identifying other aircraft and--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --lights at night behavior in the skies. And so, you have to sort of take their perceptions a little more seriously than you would, say, mine.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Right. And - and you recall earlier or actually late last year there was the situation with some Air - Air Force pilots who saw--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: --and filmed this - the video of this device sort of flying through the air and they gave a very a similar sounding description of it being very unusual.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So - so very quickly, we're almost out of time. But I'm always struck in these stories that nobody seems all that interested in following up. Do you think that--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --well why is that, do you think?

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: I - I - I've never understood this. I - I think it's because if you follow it up you're considered crazy because you're go - you're chasing after these unidentified flying objects when really we - we should be investigating this stuff to see what really is out there.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I have no idea what it is.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Not just space dust.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But it might be nice to know. And of course--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: It - it would be nice to know. Yes, indeed.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --we don't care what people say, obviously. Brett Larson, it's great to see you tonight. Thank you for looking into that--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Tucker, good to see you too. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --for us and it won't (ph) be the last time.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well unfortunately, our hour is done. What a great time that was? We will be back tomorrow night though 8:00 P.M. This is the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness, and groupthink, hopefully, a cheerful enemy. We'll be back tomorrow. Good night from Washington. Sean Hannity, live now from New York City.

utterances.speaker: SEAN HANNITY, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: All right, Tucker, Area 51, Roswell--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HANNITY
utterances.sentences: --New Mexico. Check it out.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's right. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
